factoid: Denísov was equally intimidated by his superiors and by the enemy.
Denísov came up the steps of the porch with jingling spurs.
The adjutants whispered angrily and tried to stop Denísov.
Kutúzov glanced at Denísov glumly.
Kutúzov's hands were still pressed on the seat.
Denísov had given his name.
Denísov announced that he had to communicate a matter of great importance for their country's welfare to Denísov's Serene Highness.
Kutúzov looked wearily at Denísov.
Kutúzov lifted his hands with a gesture of annoyance.
Kutúzov folded his hands across his stomach.
Kutúzov repeated the words: 'For our country's welfare? Well, what is it? Speak!'
Denísov blushed like a girl.
Denísov began to expound his plan of cutting the enemy's lines of communication between Smolénsk and Vyázma.
Denísov came from those parts.
Denísov knew the country well.
Denísov's plan seemed a good one.
Denísov spoke with strength of conviction.
Kutúzov looked down at his own legs.
Kutúzov occasionally glanced at the door of the adjoining hut.
Kutúzov expected something unpleasant to emerge from the adjoining hut.
While Denísov was speaking, a general with a portfolio under his arm appeared from the adjoining hut.
Kutúzov asked, 'What? Are you ready so soon?'
The general replied, 'Ready, your Serene Highness.'
Kutúzov swayed his head.
Kutúzov said, 'How is one man to deal with it all?'
Kutúzov listened to Denísov.
Denísov said, 'I give my word of honor as a Wussian officer that I can break Napoleon's line of communication.'
Kutúzov asked, 'What relation are you to Intendant General Kiríl Andréevich Denísov?'
Denísov replied, 'He is my uncle, your Serene Highness.'
Kutúzov said, 'Ah, we were friends.'
Kutúzov said, 'All right, all right, friend, stay here at the staff and tomorrow we’ll have a talk.'
The general nodded to Denísov.
The general turned away.
The general put out his hand for the papers Konvnítsyn had brought him.
The general asked, 'Would not your Serene Highness like to come inside?'
The general said, 'The plans must be examined and several papers have to be signed.'
An adjutant came out.
The adjutant announced that everything was in readiness within.
Kutúzov did not wish to enter the room until he was disengaged.
Kutúzov made a grimace.
Kutúzov said, 'No, tell them to bring a small table out here, my dear boy. I’ll look at them here.'
Kutúzov said, 'Don’t go away.'
Kutúzov turned to Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew remained in the porch.
Prince Andrew listened to the general's report.
